user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of set_self_name:
```c
static void
set_self_name (int argc, char *const *argv)
{
  if ((argc >= 1) && (NULL != argv[0]))
  {
    const char *last_dir_sep;
    last_dir_sep = strrchr (argv[0], '/');
#ifdef _WIN32
    if (1)
    {
      const char *last_w32_dir_sep;
      last_w32_dir_sep = strrchr (argv[0], '\\');
      if ((NULL == last_dir_sep) ||
          ((NULL != last_w32_dir_sep) && (last_w32_dir_sep > last_dir_sep)))
        last_dir_sep = last_w32_dir_sep;
    }
#endif /* _WIN32 */
    if (NULL != last_dir_sep)
    {
      size_t name_len;
      name_len = strlen (last_dir_sep + 1);
      if ((0 != name_len) && ((sizeof(self_name) / sizeof(char)) > name_len))
      {
        strcpy (self_name, last_dir_sep + 1);
        return;
      }
    }
  }
  /* Set default name */
  strcpy (self_name, "perf_replies");
  return;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function set_self_name:
static char self_name[500] = "perf_replies"
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ((argc >= 1) && (NULL != argv[0]))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The function parameter argv is declared as char *const *argv, so argv[0] has type char * (pointer to non-const char). The code only reads argv[0] (compares to NULL and passes it to strrchr/strlen/strcpy), so the pointed-to characters could and should be const-qualified. This violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. A suitable fix is to declare the parameter as const char *const *argv (or at least const char *argv[]), e.g. static void set_self_name(int argc, const char *const *argv).
